title: Fasciolopsiasis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agents

The trematode _Fasciolopsis buski_ , the largest intestinal fluke of humans.

### Life Cycle

![lifeCycle](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/modules/Fasciolopsis_LifeCycle.gif?_=05074)

Immature eggs are discharged into the intestine and stool![The number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/large_intestine_1.gif).
Eggs become embryonated in water ![The number
2](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_2.gif), eggs
release miracidia ![The number
3](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_3.gif), which
invade a suitable snail intermediate host ![The number
4](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4.gif). In the
snail the parasites undergo several developmental stages (sporocysts ![The
number 4a](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4a.gif),
rediae![The number
4b](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4b.gif), and
cercariae ![The number
4c](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4c.gif) ). The
cercariae are released from the snail ![The number
5](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_5.gif) and
encyst as metacercariae on aquatic plants ![The number
6](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/stomach_6.gif). The
mammalian hosts become infected by ingesting metacercariae on the aquatic
plants. After ingestion, the metacercariae excyst in the duodenum ![The number
7](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_7.gif)
and attach to the intestinal wall. There they develop into adult flukes (20 to
75 mm by 8 to 20 mm) in approximately 3 months, attached to the intestinal
wall of the mammalian hosts (humans and pigs) ![The number
8](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_8.gif).
The adults have a life span of about one year.

### Geographic Distribution

Asia and the Indian subcontinent, especially in areas where humans raise pigs
and consume freshwater plants.

### Clinical Presentation

Most infections are light and asymptomatic. In heavier infections, symptoms
include diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, ascites, anasarca and intestinal
obstruction.
image_gallery:
#####  _Fasciolopsis buski_ eggs.

Eggs of _Fasciolopsis buski_ are broadly ellipsoidal, operculated and measure
130-150 µm long by 60-90 µm wide. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in
feces. The eggs of _F. buski_ can be difficult to distinguish from _Fasciola
hepatica_ , although the abopercular end of the latter often has a roughened
or irregular area.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/1/F_buski_egg_wtmt_BAM1.jpg?_=05064)

Figure A: Egg of _F. buski_ in a unstained wet mount.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/1/F_buski_wtmt400_HB2.jpg?_=05060)

Figure E: Higher magnification (400x) of the egg in Figure D.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/1/F_buski_egg_wtmt_BAM2.jpg?_=05058)

Figure B: Egg of _F. buski_ in a unstained wet mount.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/1/F_buski_egg_wtmt_BAM3.jpg?_=05062)

Figure C: Egg of _F. buski_ in unstained wet mounts.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/1/F_buski_wtmt200_HB1.jpg?_=05057)

Figure D: Egg of _F. buski_ in an unstained wet mount of stool.

#####  _Fasciolopsis buski_ adults.

Adults of _F. buski_ measure 20-75 mm long and have poorly-developed oral and
ventral suckers. Adults reside in the intestine of the mammalian host.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/2/F_buski_unstained_adult1.jpg?_=05053)

Figure B: Adult fluke of F. buski.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/2/Fasciolopsis_buski_adult_GA.jpg?_=05055)

Figure A: Adult fluke of F. buski. Image contributed by Georgia Division of
Public Health.

##### Intermediate hosts of _F. buski_.

_Fasciolopsis buski_ requires a snail intermediate host for completion of its
life cycle. The snails used by _F. buski_ are small planorbid snails in the
genera _Hippeutis_ and _Segmentina_.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/3/Hippeutis_species_Poppe.jpg?_=05065)

Figure A: Snail in the genus Hippeutis, an intermediate host for _F. buski_.
Image courtesy of Conchology, Inc, Mactan Island, Philippines.

![](/dpdx/fasciolopsiasis/images/3/Segmentina_species_Poppe.jpg?_=05067)

Figure B: Snail in the genus Segmentina, an intermediate host for _F. buski_.
Image courtesy of Conchology, Inc, Mactan Island, Philippines.
lab_diagnosis:
### Laboratory Diagnosis

Microscopic identification of eggs, or more rarely of the adult flukes, in the
stool or vomitus is the basis of specific diagnosis. The eggs are
indistinguishable from those of _Fasciola hepatica_.

##### Morphology

[Morphologic comparison with other intestinal
parasites](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/diagnosticProcedures/stool/morphcomp.html)
